Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: A Quasi-Experimental Study of Corporate Policy Effects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
In response to public outcry over abusive and negative messages in social media, social media outlets are embarking on a set of policy changes to clarify existing standards and facilitate more reporting and removal of abusive content. The research will examine the effect of these rule changes on negative messages through sentiment analyses of online messages sent before and after any policy shifts. By identifying sources of individual and geographic variation in the effects of the rule changes, it will shed light on the social and cultural factors that shape responses to corporate rules and that contribute to patterns of cyber aggression. The research also will identify organizational practices that aid, or fail to aid, in limiting the negativity of everyday online interactions.

This research will use a convergence of expertise in different disciplines to accomplish its goals. Data will come from three sources: 1) online messages that target individuals on the basis of their demographic characteristics, 2) messages that contain common slurs, and 3) messages that include the location from which they were posted (geo-tagged). These will be captured and processed by extending geographic visualization and analysis techniques and information retrieval methods, and by using computational methods to compute sentiment and to assess the positivity and negativity of social media messages. Statistical analyses will show if new corporate rules result in significant decreases or possibly increases in level of sentiment negativity. They also will show whether abusive communications become more evasive and less identifiable following corporate rule changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

Our research contributes on an intellectual level both to the development of social science theory and to the accumulation of knowledge. Our project provides support for a theoretical argument that aggressive content on social media stems from two underlying processes that emerge in social interaction. These processes include 1) the reinforcement of traditional gender and race norms and stereotypes and 2) the establishment of status hierarchies, in which individuals attempt to gain recognition and status among their online followers by harassing others on the basis of gender and race. Key project findings that document modest declines in online, racist and sexist negativity in response to corporate policy changes, on the other hand, support institutionalist theories of organizational control. Our results also provide extensive empirical evidence over time of racist and sexist patterns in online, networked interactions that are relevant to multiple disciplines, including sociology, communication, racial and ethnic studies, and gender studies, and to a range of social and physical science research that studies web-based interactions.  

Several broader impacts for science and society emerge out of our project. First, our project engaged in extensive training of both undergraduate and graduate students, resulting in numerous conference presentations and research papers. The project involved both women and men, and the three graduate student coauthors on our work were from underrepresented groups. One of the published pieces that included two of these coauthors received an award, and all the work was widely disseminated at professional conferences and workshops. On a societal level, we see that Web platforms emerge as frequent conduits for problematic abusive behavior, especially directed toward women and marginalized minority groups. Our research uncovers possible, effective remedies for this serious, social problem.  

Summary of Outcomes

Our research accomplished several goals in this project. First, we uncover extensive evidence of sexist and racist online messages in social media. These hostile messages tend to reinforce negative gender and racial stereotypes and include content suggesting that women should be passive and physically attractive, for example, and that racial minorities align their behavior with traditional, demeaning stereotypes. In one of our articles (Felmlee, Inara Rodis and Zhang 2019), we find 2.9 million online messages in one week that contain instances of one of four gendered insults, with an average of 419,000 sexist slurs per day. In an award-winning study (Felmlee, Inara Rodis, and Francisco 2018; Outstanding Publication—Advances in Gender Research), we also demonstrate that hostile online content oriented towards women of color remains readily accessible, with such messages located within 30 seconds, on average. Using a social network approach, our research illustrates the tendency of abusive, social media messages to develop into interactive, network conversations where the original message spreads far beyond the victim. The potential for the extensive reach of a hostile message represents one of the reasons why such communications represent a larger, societal problem. Abusive messages on social media are not idiosyncratic in nature, furthermore, but appear to be strategic in nature and likely are intended to enhance perpetrators’ social standing among their social media followers.

An additional focus of our project concerns possible approaches to staunch racist and sexist hostility on social media. In one study (Felmlee, Dellaposta, Inara Rodis, and Matthews 2019) along these lines, we investigate the effectiveness of organizational policies intended to stem cyber aggression. This research focuses on the timing of a change on a social media platform in the rules regarding abusive content to test the effectiveness of these organizational policies. Such interventions can be effective if they are perceived as legitimate according to instrumental theories of social control, whereas such actions could instead intensify hostility in response to the sanctioning authority in a form of psychological reactance. We uncover evidence of a modest positive shift in the average sentiment of tweets with slurs targeting women and/or African-Americans, based on a sample of 3.6 million tweets over the period of one month before and one month after a social media organization policy change. We demonstrate the wide, online, network spread of these types of negative messages for specific cases and individual users. Furthermore, messages that are sent to others online are significantly more negative than those not forwarded. The patterns we uncover suggest that it remains possible for organizational "anti-abuse" policies to curtail hateful speech on social media without necessarily fueling further abuse.
